bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Robert Burridge, June 26, 1729

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Lyme Regis merchant Robert Burridge, June 26, 1729, to inform the merchant that he canot find any way of sending tobacco to him, but approves of his plan for selling tobacco sent earlier.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Robert Burridge, June 26, 1729

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
June 26. 1729
Mr. Robert Burridge

div1.p:
I receiv'd yr favour of the 23d of Decr.
and am Pleas'd with the design you had for the good dis:
pose of my Tobo sent : you to Exon and I must needs say I
have Always thought myself well serv'd by you
as by Any Person And when Ever I have an Opportunity
My design is to give you the trouble of some more of
My business

Capt Reid in Mr. Gundrys employ will
let no Freight but to his Owner if you can Prevail wth
him to take any to you next year I will god willing provide
it for you or in Any Other ship that will deliver it at yr
Port [illegible] or Exon

I forsee I shall have Tobo left this yr.
if any Vessel Offers I design to send it to you I am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
[1] It is not clear what Carter means by this word which appears twice in this letter. It can be used as an abbreviation for Exeter which is not far from Lyme Regis where Burridge lived.
[2] This may be Will Read, captain of an unnamed ship that Carter referred to in a letter to John Burridge 1727 July 28.

[3] Nathaniel Gundry was a merchant in Lyme Regis, Dorset, and mayor of that town several times. His son was a member of Parliament and later a judge. (Notes made by Francis L. Berkeley, Jr., from George Robert. History and Antiquities of the Borough of Lyme Regis & Charnmouth. [London, 1834]. pp. 97, 383-4.; and Sedgwick. The History of Parliament . . . Commons. pp. 91-92.)
